title-group.article-title: Characterization of gene regulatory elements and dynamic antimicrobial immune responses in mosquito cells using PRO-seq

abstract.p: The Aedes aegypti mosquito transmits arboviruses such as dengue, Zika, and chikungunya virus, posing a substantial threat to global health. The mosquito immune response determines virus transmission, yet, insight into the transcriptional regulation of mosquito immunity remains limited. In this study, we optimized the nascent RNA-sequencing method Precision Run-On sequencing (PRO-seq) for Aedes aegypti Aag2 cells. PRO-seq enabled profiling the distribution of active RNA polymerases across the mosquito genome at nucleotide precision and identified the exact transcription start nucleotides (TSN) of expressed genes. Based on exact positioning of the TSN, we uncovered core promoter elements, including the Initiator and Downstream Promoter Elements. Notably, RNA polymerase accumulates at the promoter-proximal region of genes, but transcribes into the divergent region to a lesser extent than in vertebrates. To investigate rapid and dynamic immune responses, Aag2 cells were immune-stimulated with heat-inactivated E. coli for 1 and 4 hours. Differential gene expression analysis revealed different groups of genes to be induced over time. While Clip domain serine proteases and antimicrobial peptides were induced promptly and sustained, a delayed stress response consisting of heat shock-related genes was only seen at 4 hours after stimulation. Strikingly, gene sets with different temporal expression profiles were associated with distinct transcription factor binding motifs. Altogether, our study provides valuable insights into the functional genomics of Aedes aegypti and indicates that even within a rapid response, different dynamics emerge, potentially regulated by distinct transcription factors. These insights are crucial to gain a better understanding of the mosquito immune response and its regulation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hematophagous insects, in particular mosquitoes, are important biological vectors for the transmission of arthropod-borne (arbo) viruses. Emerging and re-emerging epidemic arboviruses including dengue, Zika, and chikungunya pose a significant threat to global health with currently about half of the human population living at risk of infection (1, 2). Epidemic arboviruses rely on transmission by mosquitoes from the Aedes genus, primarily Ae. aegypti. This urban-adapted mosquito species originated from Africa, but, due to increased global trade and travel, is now endemic in tropical and subtropical regions all over the world (3).

Arbovirus transmission from mosquito to humans requires active infection of mosquitoes (4, 5). Mosquito-intrinsic factors, including stress responses and antiviral immune defense control virus replication and therefore determine the efficiency of transmission (6, 7). Importantly, besides arboviruses, mosquitoes are naturally infected with environmental microbes such as bacteria, fungi, and insect-specific viruses that interact within the insect in a mutualistic or pathogenic relationship (8). This results in an intriguing triangular interaction of the mosquito host, environmental microbes and human-pathogenic viruses, that can directly or indirectly impact arbovirus transmission (8–12). It is therefore critical to obtain a holistic view of mosquito host responses to various microbes.

A critical cornerstone of mosquito host responses are inducible immune pathways (6, 7). Particularly, two nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB)-related pathways, Toll and Immune deficiency (Imd), and the Janus kinase and Signal Transducers and Activators of Transcription (JAK-STAT) pathway, have been implicated in mosquito immune responses to various microbial challenges (13, 14). Generally, inducible immune pathways are triggered upon recognition of foreign molecular signatures, which will activate an intracellular signaling cascade to induce distinct gene expression programs (15). In insects, transcriptional responses to bacterial and fungal infection through the Toll and IMD pathways induce the expression of distinct classes of antimicrobial genes (16). Moreover, these NF-κB related pathways, in addition to the JAK-STAT signaling cascade, have been recognized as part of the antiviral defense, although it remains unclear how changes in gene expression programs eventually confer immunity against virus infection (6).

Transcriptional responses to pathogen infections rely on interplay of distinct molecular mechanisms (17). Importantly, immune responses are highly dynamic and involve both cis-acting regulatory elements encoded in the DNA as well as trans-acting factors that ensure coordinated regulation of chromatin and transcriptional reprogramming (17). However, the annotation of regulatory elements such as promotors and enhancers in the Ae. aegypti genome is largely missing, preventing a comprehensive characterization of transcriptional kinetics and the underlying mechanisms that govern immune responses. Moreover, we currently lack experimental tools to capture dynamic changes in gene expression in mosquitoes. Investigating molecular mechanisms that coordinate such dynamic transcriptional responses have been enabled by development of nascent RNA sequencing techniques. In contrast to conventional RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) methods that measure steady-state transcript levels, these techniques track the process of RNA synthesis and measure the levels of newly synthetized RNA species (18). Nascent RNA sequencing therefore detects both stable and unstable RNA species and quantifies dynamic changes of gene expression at high resolution and sensitivity. Different nascent RNA sequencing techniques have been developed (18); amongst which Precision Run-On sequencing (PRO-seq). In PRO-seq, RNA polymerase incorporates a single biotinylated nucleotide (nt) to the active site of transcription (the 3’-end of a nascent transcript), after which it stalls due to steric hindrance of the biotin (19). Streptavidin-mediated purification of these labeled transcripts enables selective enrichment of nascent RNAs and provides a genome-wide snapshot of positions and orientations of engaged RNA Polymerases at nucleotide precision. Apart from the highly sensitive and dynamic quantification of nascent RNA synthesis, PRO-seq has proven to be a powerful approach to identify the precise transcription start sites (TSS), termed here Transcription Start Nucleotides (TSN, +1-nt).

Here, we adapted PRO-seq for Ae. aegypti cells to unveil dynamic host responses to immune challenges and identify regulatory mechanisms that underlie rapid changes in gene expression. Profiting from the data richness of PRO-seq, we improved the TSS annotation of the Ae. aegypti genome with the precise TSNs, which enabled us to identify functional regions across the Ae. aegypti genome, and gene sets under control of different core promotor elements such as Initiator, TATA box and Downstream Promoter Elements. Making use of this improved functional genome annotation, we performed differential gene expression analysis at two early timepoints after bacterial stimulation of mosquito cells. We observed hundreds of differentially expressed genes and identified different kinetics of gene expression after the immune challenge. Strikingly, genes with differential dynamics also show differential enrichment of transcription factor binding motifs, indicating that distinct transcriptional regulators coordinate temporal patterns of gene expression upon immune challenge. In conclusion, tracking engaged RNA polymerase molecules at nucleotide-resolution uncovered cis-acting regulatory elements, functional genomic regions, and mechanisms that underlie transcriptional responses upon immune challenge of Ae. aegypti mosquitoes.

sec.title: Cell culture
sec.p: The C3PC12 clone of Ae. aegypti Aag2 cells (20) was cultured at 28°C in Leibovitz’s L-15 medium (Invitrogen) supplemented with filter-sterilized and heat inactivated 10% fetal calf serum (Gibco), 50 U/ml Penicillin (Invitrogen), 50 µg/ml Streptomycin (Invitrogen), 1x non-essential amino acids (Invitrogen), and 2% tryptose phosphate broth (Sigma). K562 cells were cultured at 37°C, 5% CO2 in RPMI 1640 + Glutamax supplemented with filter-sterilized and heat inactivated 10% fetal calf serum (Gibco), 50 U/ml Penicillin (Invitrogen), and 50 µg/ml Streptomycin (Invitrogen).

sec.title: Preparation of heat-killed E.coli and stimulation of Aag2 cells
sec.p: E. coli (XL10-Gold) cultures were grown overnight in LB medium and harvested by centrifugation at 6,800 g for 3 minutes. Bacterial pellets were washed twice and resuspended in PBS at OD600 = 1. For heat inactivation, bacteria were incubated at 95 °C for 15 minutes. Heat killed bacteria were aliquoted and long-term stored at -80 °C. To verify heat inactivation, a sample of the bacterial suspension was inoculated onto LB agar plates and incubated at 37 °C overnight. Efficient heat kill resulted in the complete absence of bacterial colonies on LB agar plates. To stimulate Aag2 cells, heat inactivated E.coli were equilibrated to room temperature and the bacterial suspension was directly added to the Aag2 cell culture medium at a final concentration of OD600 = 0.05. Treatment of cells with an equal volume of PBS served as negative control.

sec.title: Chromatin isolation
sec.p: Chromatin samples for PRO-seq were prepared according to (21), with small modifications. Approximately 30 million Aag2 cells were washed with ice-cold PBS before harvesting with a cell scraper. Cells were pelleted by centrifuging at 400 x g for 5 minutes at 4 °C. After a second wash with ice-cold PBS, cells were resuspended in 1 ml ice-cold NUN buffer (20 mM HEPES pH 7.5, 300 mM NaCl, 1M Urea, 1% NP-40 Substitute, 7.5 mM MgCl2, 0.2 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, 20 units per ml RNase inhibitor, 1x Protease Inhibitor Cocktail) and vortexed vigorously for one minute. Subsequently, the chromatin was pelleted by centrifuging at 12,500 x g for 30 minutes at 4 °C. Chromatin was resuspended in 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, vortexed briefly and spun down at 10,000 x g, for 5 min at 4 °C After another Tris-HCl wash, the chromatin was resuspended in chromatin storage buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0, 25% glycerol, 5 mM MgCH3COO)2, 0.1 mM EDTA, 5 mM DTT, 40 units per ml RNase inhibitor) and incubated for 5 minutes on ice. Chromatin samples were fragmented by sonication (Bioruptor pico, Diagenode) with 10 cycles of 30 seconds on / 30 sec off intervals at high throughput settings, flash-frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80 °C. For optimization of PRO-seq for Aag2 cells, chromatin was sonicated for another 5 cycles just before the run-on reaction.

sec.title: Run-on reaction
sec.p: The 2x Run-on Master Mix (ROMM: 10 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0, 5 mM MgCl2, 1 mM DTT, 300 mM KCl, 40μM Biotin-11-CTP (Perkin Elmer), 40μM Biotin-11-UTP (Perkin Elmer), 40 μM ATP (Thermo Fisher), 40μM GTP (Thermo Fisher), 0.8 units/μl RNase inhibitor, 1% Sarkosyl) was prepared and pre-warmed to 37 °C. Meanwhile, chromatin was thawed on ice, and K562 chromatin was added to Aag2 as spike-in. To reach 1% spike-in, chromatin from 100.000 K562 cells was added to each chromatin sample of 30 million Aag2 cells. To start the run-on reaction, an equal volume of ROMM was added to the chromatin and thoroughly mixed by pipetting up and down, followed by incubation at 37 °C for 5 minutes.

sec.title: Isolation of nascent transcripts
sec.p: To terminate the run-on reaction, 500 μl TRIzol LS (Thermo Fisher) and 130 μl chloroform (Merck) were added and samples were homogenized by vortexing, incubated on ice for 1 minute and then centrifuged at 18,000 x g for 5 minutes at 4 °C. RNA in the aqueous phase was precipitated with 100% ethanol, using GlycoBlue (Invitrogen) as co-precipitant, and washed with 75% ethanol. RNA pellets were air-dried for 5 minutes, diluted in RNase-free water and base hydrolyzed with NaOH for 5 minutes, after which the reaction was neutralized with 1 M Tris-HCl, pH 6.8. To remove free biotinylated nucleotides, the RNA was passed through P-30 columns (Bio-Rad). Nascent RNAs, with biotinylated 3’-ends, were purified by Streptavidin Dynabeads (Thermo Fisher) and washed with Binding, High Salt and Low Salt wash buffers (Binding buffer: 10mM Tris-Cl pH 7.4, 300 mM NaCl, 0.1% Triton X-100, High Salt wash buffer: 50 mM Tris-Cl pH 7.4, 2M NaCl, 0.5% Triton X-100 and Low Salt wash buffer: 5 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 0.1% Triton X-100). Subsequently, the nascent RNAs were released from the beads through TRIzol/chloroform-based RNA isolation, precipitated with 100% ethanol and washed with 75% ethanol.

sec.title: 3’ barcoding and pooling of samples
sec.p: Sequencing adapters with unique barcodes for each sample (Table 1) were ligated to the 3’ end of the purified nascent RNAs. To this end, 1 µl of 25 µM 3’adapters was added to the nascent RNA, followed by denaturation at 65 °C for 1 minute and incubation in ice water for 1 minute. To each sample, 20 U T4 RNA ligase (NEB) was added and incubated at 25 °C overnight. To remove the non-ligated 3’ adapters, nascent RNA samples were purified with Streptavidin Dynabeads as described above. Afterwards, the barcoded samples were pooled per timepoint per replicate.

sec.title: 5’ de-capping, 5’ hydroxy-repair and 5’ adapter ligation
sec.p: The nascent RNAs bound to Streptavidin Dynabeads were 5’ de-capped by diluting in RNA 5’ Pyrophosphohydrolase (RppH) mix (NEB) and incubation at 37 °C for 45 minutes. Subsequently, 5’ ends were hydroxy-repaired by adding T4 polynucleotide kinase reaction mix (NEB) which was incubated for 45 minutes at 37 °C. For elution of RNA from the beads, the beads were first washed with High Salt and Low Salt wash buffers, and RNA was isolated with TRIzol/chloroform as described above. After air-drying for 5 minutes, the RNA pellets were resuspended in adapter mix with 1 µl of 25 µM 5’ adapter (Table 1) and ATP, and incubated at 65 °C and subsequently in ice-cold water, each for one minute. Subsequently, the ligation mix with 20 U T4 RNA Ligase buffer (NEB) was added and incubated for 3 hours at 25 °C. To remove the non-ligated 5’ adapters, nascent RNA transcripts were purified with Streptavidin Dynabeads and isolated with TRIzol/chloroform, as described above.

sec.title: Reverse-transcription and amplification
sec.p: The RNA pellets from the previous step, containing the 3’ and 5’ adapter-ligated nascent RNA transcripts, were diluted in a mix containing RP1 primer (Table 1) and dNTPs (Thermo Fisher), followed by denaturation at 65 °C for 1 minute and incubation in ice water for 1 minute. Reverse transcription was performed with Super Script III reverse transcriptase. The reverse-transcribed samples were amplified with Phusion High-Fidelity Polymerase and primers RP1 and RPI-n (Table 1), using the following cycling conditions: 95°C for 2 min; 5 cycles of 95°C for 30 sec, 56°C for 30 sec and 72°C for 30 sec; 5 cycles of 95°C for 30 sec, 65°C for 30 sec and 72°C for 30 sec; final extension at 72°C for 10 min. For library clean-up and size-selection, a 1.4x volume of Mag-Bind® TotalPure NGS beads (Omega bio-tek) was used. Library concentration and size distribution were determined with Qubit dsDNA High Sensitivity Kit and Bioanalyzer High Sensitivity DNA Analysis.

sec.title: Paired-end deep sequencing
sec.p: The uniquely barcoded libraries were mixed in equimolar volume for sequencing. Paired-end sequencing was performed on a NovaSeq6000 with 51nt(Read1)-10nt(Index1)-10nt(Index2)-51nt(Read2) setup by the sequencing facility of the National Genomics Infrastructure (Stockholm, Sweden).

sec.title: De-multiplexing and read trimming
sec.p: Replicates were demultiplexed based on 5’ barcode by the sequencing facility of the National Genomics Infrastructure (Stockholm, Sweden), after which the read-1s of individual samples were de-multiplexed based on 3’ barcode with fastx_barcode_splitter. Corresponding read-2s were paired back with fastq_pair. Reads were trimmed for adapters and UMI with fastp. The 3’ barcode was trimmed at the start of read1 with fastx_trimmer and in the case of readthrough, at the end of read2 with cutadapt. The reverse complement of read1 was obtained with fastx_reverse_complement.

sec.title: Alignment and deduplication
sec.p: Trimmed reads were first aligned to ribosomal genes and their flanking 50 basepairs, after which the mapped reads were discarded from further analysis. The rRNA gene annotation was based AaegL5.3 gff file version 3. The ribosomal-depleted reads were mapped to the total Ae. aegypti genome (AaegL5.3) and the spike-in human genome (T2T-chm13v2). All alignments were performed with bowtie2 --dovetail and only reads in concordant pairs, including multimappers, were kept for downstream analysis. PCR-duplicated reads were removed with UMItools.

sec.title: File conversions
sec.p: Mapped and deduplicated reads in bam file were converted to bed files describing the inserts from read1 and read2 together as 1 fragment. From these bed files the 5’ and 3’ nt positions were extracted. Non-normalized bedgraph files based on 5’ and 3’ counts were generated with bedtools genomecov, and subsequently normalized based on spike-in reads.

sec.title: Identification of the Transcription Start Nucleotide
sec.p: Currently annotated transcription start sites were retrieved from AaegL5.3 gff version 3, and regions of TSS - 100 nt and TSS + 400 nt were extracted. PRO-seq 5’ nt reads were pooled per replicate (each containing 4 samples). The nucleotide position with the highest 5’ nt PRO-seq coverage was determined (maxPos) for either replicate. Per replicate, only the upper median of max positions were kept to generate a list of Transcription Start Nucleotides (TSN). Transcripts for which the called nucleotide was the same for both replicates, were annotated with the exact TSN.

sec.title: Core promoter elements and sequence logo
sec.p: For the transcripts for which we defined the TSN with PRO-seq 5’ nt coverage, we generated bed files of 100 nt windows around the currently annotated TSS and the experimentally identified TSN. Fasta files, generated through bedtools getfasta, were then searched for sense match to the Drosophila melanogaster consensus motifs; TATAWAW for TATA box, TAKTY for Initiator and RGWYV for Downstream Promoter Element. To visualize the distribution of their positioning, we used ggplot2 geom_density. This function computes and draws the kernel density estimate as a smoothened version of a histogram (22). To generate sequence logos, the same 100 nt window bed files were used as input for Weblogo (weblogo.berkeley.edu) (23).

sec.title: Visualization of genomic data
sec.p: Coverage track files were visualized with IGV genome browser. ChIP-seq and ATAC-seq bigwig files (24) were RPM-normalized, and PRO-seq 5’ and 3’ nt bedgraph files were spike-in normalized. Metaplots were generated with deepTools computematrix.

sec.title: Quantification of Pol II densities at genomic loci
sec.p: To count PRO-seq 3’ nt reads over genome features, genes were partitioned as follows: divergent (TSS-750 to TSS-100), promoter proximal (TSS-100 to TSS+100), +5 nucleosomes (TSS+100 to TSS+1000), remaining gene body (TSS+1000 to CPS-100), cleavage and polyA signal (CPS-100 to CPS+100) and termination window (CPS+100 to CPS+5 kb). The CPS location was retrieved as the transcription end site from the AaegL5.3 gff file version 3. The TSS locations were updated to TSN according to PRO-seq 5’ nt coverage where applicable. To define transposable elements, we extracted the AaegL5 repeatfeatures from VectorBase and filtered out the following regions “dust”, “trf”, “simple_repeat”, “rRNA”, “tRNA”, “low_complexity”, leaving all types of transposable elements. Reads within each region were counted with bedtools intersect (see also Figure S3A), using the –s setting to count in a strand-specific manner and –S to count for the opposite strand.

sec.title: Differential expression analysis and functional classification
sec.p: For differential expression analysis, we performed DESeq2 on spike-in normalized PRO-seq 3’ nt reads mapping to the gene body (TSS + 100 to CPS – 100) with p-value < 0.05 and fold change > 1.5. Differentially expressed genes per timepoint were characterized with DAVID Functional Annotation Clustering (25).

sec.title: Clustering and motif analysis
sec.p: To cluster and visualize the expression of transcripts robustly induced (log2 fold change > 1) at either 1 or 4 hours post stimulation, we performed k-means clustering and generated a heatmap with R package ComplexHeatmap. Motif enrichment analysis for promoters (here set from TSS-1000 to TSS) was performed with HOMER findMotifs.pl. The top 5 motifs per cluster were extracted and used for motif occurrence analysis with HOMER findMotifs.pl as well, after which similar motifs where combined.

sec.title: Optimization of PRO-seq for the Aedes aegypti mosquito Aag2 cells
sec.p: In order to study transcriptional regulation upon immune challenge in Aedes aegypti, we established PRO-seq in the Aag2 cell line. To benchmark the experimental procedure, we took along human K562 cells, in which PRO-seq has been successfully performed previously (26, 27). After incorporation of biotinylated nucleotides during nuclear run-on of RNA polymerases, nascent RNA was biochemically purified using streptavidin beads (Fig. S1A). Nascent RNA was then subjected to Illumina deep-sequencing library preparation. At the final step, the quality of PCR amplified libraries was checked by gel electrophoresis. PRO-seq libraries were successfully obtained for both human and mosquito cells (Fig. S1B, C); however, we observed a prominent unexpected peak of low molecular weight specifically in the electrophoresis profile of the mosquito samples (Fig. S1C), suggesting the presence of adapter dimers in mosquito-derived samples. To reduce adapter contamination, we implemented several changes in the PRO-seq library preparation (Fig. S1A). First, we performed an extra five cycles of sonication and omitted the RNA purification step after the P-30 columns (see materials & methods) to improve nascent RNA recovery. Moreover, to enhance the formation of true nascent RNA-adapter conjugates, we doubled the concentration of RNA ligase while reducing the concentration of both 5’ and 3’ RNA adapters by half. In addition, tubes were switched at all washes to decrease free-floating adapters. The incorporation of these changes, resulted in a profound reduction of adapter dimers in the sequencing libraries (Fig. S1D), enabling us to perform nascent RNA sequencing in mosquito cells.

sec.title: PRO-seq identifies exact transcription start nucleotide and core-promotor elements
sec.p: Using the optimized PRO-seq procedure we sequenced nascent RNAs from untreated and bacterial-stimulated Aag2 cells at two timepoints (for details, see below). Before analyzing the effect of immune challenge, we first used the sequencing libraries to characterize fundamental features of transcriptional regulation in mosquito cells. We therefore inspected the distribution of the 5’ and 3’ terminal nucleotides of PRO-seq reads, which give detailed insights into the genome-wide distribution of transcription start sites and active RNA polymerases, two essential parameters for studying the regulation of transcription. In the transcription initiation window, the accumulation of 5’ terminal nucleotides can be used to identify the exact Transcription Start Nucleotide (TSN or +1 nt; Fig. 1A). In contrast to the wider distributions of conventional RNA-sequencing tracks (Fig. 1B, C), the sharp distribution of 5’ PRO-seq peaks greatly facilitates calling of the exact nucleotide position. Indeed, we observed that only for a minority of genes, the peak of 5’ nt coverage coincided exactly with the TSS currently annotated for the Ae. aegypti genome (Fig. 1B). Instead, for most genes, the 5’ peak was located more downstream (Fig. 1C). Strikingly, in both scenarios, the 5’ peaks from PRO-seq data coincided with a strong accumulation of downstream RNA-sequencing reads and the Initiator (Inr) motif (Fig. 1B, C), which is reported to occur exactly on the (28). These findings support that TSN calling by PRO-seq strongly outperforms the currently available gene annotation. We therefore systematically called and analyzed TSNs based on the PRO-seq 5’ nt data (Fig. S2A). In this way, almost 40% of all mosquito transcription start sites could be pinpointed to an exact TSN. For each of these, we calculated the distance between the currently annotated TSS position and the exact called TSN, showing an overall downstream shift, with an average deviation of 55 nt and a median deviation of 27 nt (Fig. 1D). To validate the TSN positioning, we next analyzed the presence of core promoter elements in a 100-nt window around the TSS from either the current or the PRO-seq based TSN. For 12,881 genes with detectable PRO-seq read coverage (Fig. S2A), we specifically analyzed the positioning of the TATA box, the Initiator motif and the downstream promoter element (DPE) (Fig. 1E, upper panel). The TATA box has been reported to locate approximately 30 nt upstream of the gene start (28). Somewhat surprisingly, we only identified less than 300 promotors that contained a TATA box both in the vicinity of currently annotated TSSs and PRO-seq informed TSNs. Yet, only for the exact TSN, the TATA box motif was positioned around the expected 30 nt upstream of the transcription initiation site (28) (Fig. 1E, left panel). Even more striking results were obtained when we analyzed the positioning of Inr motif and DPE. Based on the current gene annotation, both elements could be identified in close proximity of more than 2600 and 4000 TSSs, however, their distribution was near random and not enriched at the expected position (Fig. 1E, middle and left panel). Using PRO-seq to call TSNs increased the number of identified promotor elements and showed strong positioning of the Inr and DPE elements at the expected distance relative to the TSN. Indeed, the central adenine nucleotide of the Inr motif occurred exactly at the TSN predicted by PRO-seq 5’ peaks (Fig. 1E, middle panel).

To support these findings with an independent analysis, we generated sequence logos of the core promoter regions from all 12,881 TSNs that showed accumulation of a specific 5’ peak in our PRO-seq data. In parallel, we performed the same analysis for these genes considering the current TSS annotation. Strikingly, no sequence enrichment for the core promoter elements was observed based on current TSS annotation (Fig 1F, insert), while core promoters around TSNs called with PRO-seq show strong enrichment of the Inr motif and downstream DPE (Fig. 1F). The use of PRO-seq 5’ nt tracks therefore proves to be an accurate method to annotate the exact start site of transcription at nucleotide resolution. For any further analysis in this study, we have therefore used our improved TSN annotation.

sec.title: Genome-wide analysis of RNA-polymerase distribution
sec.p: We next analyzed the distribution of 3’ terminal nucleotides of PRO-seq reads (Fig. S3A) to trace the position of active RNA polymerase. As expected, the majority of 3’ nt reads mapped to gene regions (Fig. S3B). Besides this, a considerable portion of almost 20% mapped to intergenic transposable elements, reflecting the high content of actively transcribed transposon sequences in the Ae. aegypti genome (29). About a quarter of PRO-seq reads could not be assigned to any currently defined genomic feature. Noteworthy, the fraction of these unassigned reads was reduced to about 5% when also attribution to the opposite genomic strand was permitted (Fig. S3B), suggesting antisense transcription occurs at genes and transposable elements.

We next analyzed the positioning of RNA polymerase over gene regions in more detail. In vertebrate cells, RNA polymerases strongly accumulate at the promotor-proximal region near the 5’ end of actively transcribed genes before entering productive elongation through the gene body (30). This behavior is visible by a prominent peak of PRO-seq 3’ terminal nucleotides just downstream of the TSS. Moreover, short divergent RNA transcripts accumulate upstream of the TSS, indicative of RNA polymerase engaging in non-productive transcription on the opposite DNA strand. At the 3’ end of genes an additional, often less pronounced peak is evident, reflecting the slowdown of RNA polymerases prior to transcription termination which includes transcript cleavage and polyadenylation (30)(Fig. 2A). Similar to vertebrates, RNA polymerase in mosquito cells most prominently accumulates in a promotor proximal window spanning nucleotides 100 nt downstream of the TSS (Fig. 2B, C). More specifically, two main peaks around +30 nt and +50 nt are seen, which likely reflect the early and late pause site (31). Interestingly, however, only little divergent transcription upstream of the TSS is seen (Fig. 2B), indicating that the majority of promoters in the mosquito genome do not favor bi-directional initiation of RNA polymerase but are instead uni-directional, similar to Drosophila but unlike vertebrate genes (32–34). Noteworthy, this is not a universal feature for all Ae. aegypti genes as for specific promoters, divergent transcripts are detected (Fig. S3D). Moreover, the accumulation of RNA polymerase near the 3’ end is not evident in mosquito cells, suggesting that transcription termination is not associated with a slowdown in RNA polymerase processivity (Fig. 2B).

We next aimed to comprehensively quantify the distribution of active RNA polymerases over the different parts of actively transcribed genes, from here on referred to as functional genomic regions. We divided Ae. aegypti genes into six distinct regions (Fig. 2A): the promotor proximal region was defined as the genomic region 100 basepairs (bp) up- and downstream of the TSS. The window for divergent transcription was annotated further upstream reaching up to -750 bp. Downstream of the promotor proximal window we separately demarcated the first 1000 bp from the remainder of the gene body, approximately reflecting the first five nucleosomes which are important for the deposition of histone modifications at gene promotors. Finally, we defined the cleavage and polyadenylation window as 100 bp up- and downstream region flanking the cleavage and polyadenylation site (CPS) and the termination window up to 5000 bp downstream of the CPS (Fig. 2A). Active genes (Fig. 2D) shows readily detectable levels of PRO-seq 3’ nt reads distribute over these functional genomic regions, while virtually no PRO-seq 3’ nt reads map to inactive genes that are silenced by repressive H3K9 trimethylation marks (Fig. 2E). By summing the PRO-seq 3’ nt reads per functional genomic region for all genes, we obtained a distribution of RNA polymerase over genes. As shown before, this distribution also showed little accumulation of RNA polymerase at divergent and CPS regions, and the highest fractions for gene bodies and promoter proximal regions, the latter confirming the RNA polymerase accumulation at the start of genes. (Fig. 2F, Fig. S3C).

sec.title: Dynamic control of host responses to bacterial stimulation
sec.p: The identification of critical gene regulatory elements and RNA polymerase distribution highlights the value of PRO-seq data for characterizing transcriptional regulation in non-model organisms. Next, we set out to compare the dynamic transcriptional regulation in mosquito cells upon immune challenge. To this end, we stimulated mosquito cells with heat-inactivated (HI) E. coli, which is known to result in robust induction of antimicrobial gene expression (35, 36). We collected chromatin samples for PRO-seq at one and four hours post immune challenge (Fig. 3A) and PBS-treated cells were taken along as negative controls at both timepoints. To analyze differential gene expression, we quantified the number of normalized PRO-seq 3’ terminal nucleotides located within the gene body (including the +5 nucleosome window; see Fig. 2A) as precise estimate of expression independent of polymerase stalling. As expected, bacterial stimulation triggered a robust transcriptional response at both analyzed timepoints (Fig. 3B, C). Strikingly, the strongest transcriptional response occurred already one hour post stimulation (Fig. 3B), whereas at four hours post stimulation the number of actively transcribed genes already started to decline (Fig. 3C), suggesting that at least part of the antimicrobial host response relies on a rapid, transient burst of transcription.

To characterize the functional differences within such a rapid response, we performed functional annotation clustering with the Database for Annotation, Visualization and Integrated Discovery (DAVID) on the differentially expressed genes. In this analysis, Uniprot Keywords, Gene Ontology terms and INTERPRO protein domains are integrated to extract non-redundant groups of genes that share common biological functions. At both timepoints, enrichment of a group with Clip domain serine protease (CLIP) genes (Fig. 3C, Fig. S4A, Fig. S4K) and a group with antimicrobial peptides (AMP) genes (Fig. 3C, Fig. S4B, Fig. S4L) is seen. However, also differences between the timepoints are apparent. For example, a group describing transferrins is only enriched at one hour post immune stimulation (Fig. 3C, Fig. S4D). Also, serine protease inhibitors, described to play a role in negative feedback of CLIP protease activity (37), were only enriched at one hour (Fig. 3C, Fig. S4C). Interestingly, at 4 hours post immune stimulus, a significant enrichment of genes associated with heat shock and endoplasmic reticulum stress was seen (Fig. 3C, Fig. S4M), indicating a delayed stress response. These findings strongly suggest that even within rapid responses and narrow timeframes, functional and organizational differences emerge.

sec.title: Temporal expression patterns are associated with distinct transcription factor motifs
sec.p: After functional analysis of the differentially expressed genes, we aimed to identify potential differences in transcriptional regulation underlying such organization. To this end, we included all transcripts robustly upregulated (log2 fold change > 1) at 1h or 4h for clustering analysis, revealing three distinct clusters. Cluster 1 consists of 96 transcripts that were robustly induced at one hour post infection but that showed no or little synthesis at the four hour timepoint (Fig. 4A, upper cluster), indicating a dynamic, short-lived transcriptional response. The 141 transcripts in cluster 2 were induced at one hour post bacterial stimulation and remained actively transcribed also four hours after challenge (Fig. 4A, middle cluster). Finally, cluster 3 consists of 27 transcript that showed a slower response with no or little induction at one hour but robust transcription four hour after bacterial stimulation (Fig. 4A, lower cluster).

To identify the regulators responsible for these distinct temporal expression patterns, we searched for known transcription factor (TF) binding motifs in a 1 kb window upstream of the TSS (38). Strikingly, we observed enriched binding sites for multiple TFs, including the NF-κB-related Rel1/2 motif (13), indicating that, as expected, transcriptional induction was regulated by Toll and/or Imd signaling (Fig. S5A). In addition, we found enrichment of binding sites for multiple transcription factors of the AP-1 family and the GATA family group (Fig. S5A). Interestingly, the presence of transcription factor binding motifs segregated with the temporal expression pattern of immune-responsive host transcripts (Fig. 4B). Transcripts activated rapidly and sustained until four hours, exhibited a strong enrichment for the NF-κB Rel1/2 motif (Fig. 4B). In contrast, transiently expressed transcripts that were quickly upregulated but no longer actively transcribed at 4 hours post stimulation, showed the highest enrichment for GATA and AP-1 motifs (Fig. 4B). Transcripts from cluster 3, being most induced at 4 hours post stimulation, showed highest enrichment for the TEAD2 motif (Fig. 4B). These findings suggest that distinct temporal expression patterns are governed by specific combinations of transcriptions factors (Fig. 4C).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Swift transcriptional adaptation of gene expression to cope with the physiological challenges of pathogen infection is a fundamental aspect of immune responses across all domains of life (6, 39–43). Pioneering studies on dynamic transcriptional responses upon acute stress such as heat shock have profited from nascent RNA sequencing methods (16, 17). Nascent RNA sequencing captures direct transcriptional changes independent of steady state RNA levels and transcript stability, enabling the characterization of dynamic regulatory changes. Here, we adapted PRO-seq (19) to sequence nascent RNAs upon bacterial stimulation and characterized the regulation of the transcriptional immune response in Ae. aegypti cells. Leveraging the richness of PRO-seq data, we revised the current annotation of transcription start sites to the exact start nucleotide for about 40% of Ae. aegypti transcripts. This reannotation was critical to identify core promotor elements. In addition, we profiled the accumulation of active RNA polymerases across the Ae. aegypti genome in Aag2 cells and used these data to quantify active transcription in response to bacterial immune challenge. We confirmed rapid and robust induction of gene expression one and four hours after E. coli stimulation. While induction of canonical immune genes such as CLIP proteases and AMPs was sustained during the time course, other genes showed only transient or delayed induction, such as heat shock-related genes. Strikingly, the temporal expression patterns of induced transcripts associated with distinctive transcription factors binding sites that could (co-)regulate the expression of these separate groups of genes. Our data suggest that regulation of transcriptional dynamics is critical to ensure coordinated gene expression in response to pathogen challenge.

This study was the first to use PRO-seq in mosquito cells. We found that, while the basic principles of the method still apply, it is critical to carefully optimize the procedure to the desired experimental system. For Aag2 cells, the ratio of adapters to input material required optimization in order to reduce adapter dimers in the sequencing library which may be the result of differences in transcriptional activity between cell types. PRO-seq is most efficient in fast-dividing cells, such as cancer cells, that are inherently more transcriptionally active, facilitating capture of nascent RNA. Noteworthy, ongoing developments of PRO-seq variants, such as click-chemistry based protocols (44), will aid in extending the application of PRO-seq to settings where nascent RNA content is expected to be more limited, such as for primary cells or tissue samples.

PRO-seq is a powerful nascent RNA sequencing method that enables the characterization of highly dynamic transcriptional processes while at the same time providing information about cis-acting regulatory elements. This makes it a particularly valuable approach for the accurate annotation of genomes of non-model organisms. Indeed, PRO-seq data enabled us to define exact transcription start nucleotides, having more precision than the current TSS annotation, which is based on conventional RNA sequencing data. We found that the TSS predictions often are too inclusive by calling the most upstream site with RNA coverage. The exact definition of start nucleotides is further impeded by the usually wide distribution of RNA sequencing reads at the 5’ and 3’ ends of transcripts. In contrast, the PRO-seq reads located at the start of a gene often converge in a single dominant peak allowing a highly accurate estimate of the exact TSN location. An overall deviation between annotated TSSs and the exact TSN, with a downstream shift of the TSN, has also been reported for Drosophila melanogaster and Homo sapiens (31, 32, 45).

Importantly, determination of TSNs at high accuracy was instrumental to identify core promotor elements including TATA box, Initiator, and Downstream promotor elements. Only when considering TSNs called by PRO-seq we could observed a profound enrichment of the center ‘A’ of the initiator motif exactly at the first transcribed nucleotide and the downstream promotor elements precisely at the expected +28 position (28). Intriguingly, the possibility to experimentally define exact TSNs will be critical to study the differential use of TSNs between different cell types or upon stimuli, as another level of transcriptional regulation (46).

The nature of PRO-seq, which relies on biochemical purification of polymerase-associated nascent RNAs, allows profiling of the global transcriptional output irrespective of the nature of the transcript and the type of polymerase involved in RNA synthesis. In mosquito cells, we identified more than half of the nascent transcripts to be derived from annotated genes and about 20% at sequences of transposable elements. 25% of the mapped nascent RNAs could not be attributed to any genomic feature, but this fraction was profoundly reduced when disregarding sequence orientation. While a fraction of this improved attribution could be explained by background reads, our data suggests antisense transcription at gene and transposon loci. Especially for transposable elements, this antisense transcription is not unexpected. In fact, many transposon sequences are located in so-called PIWI-interacting RNA (piRNA) clusters (47). These genomic loci are core elements of a transposon defense mechanism and are enriched for defective transposable elements that are integrated in antisense orientation to the direction of transcription. It would therefore be intriguing to further research these loci, and the proportion of PRO-seq reads assigned to the opposite strand of annotated genomic features.

When assessing RNA polymerase positioning across individual genes, we found a predominant accumulation at promotor-proximal regions from where polymerase is primarily released into the gene body (30). The two main peaks around +30 and +50 nt suggest an early and late pausing site, as also reported for Drosophila melanogaster and Homo sapiens (31, 45, 48). Noteworthy, only little transcription is seen at divergent regions, indicating that most Ae. aegypti promoters seem to be unidirectional. This is similar to what has been reported for promotors in Drosophila, yet in sharp contrast to the bidirectional nature of most vertebrate promoters (32, 33, 49). Accumulation of RNA polymerases near the transcription termination site was less pronounced than in vertebrates, suggesting more efficient cleavage of nascent transcripts and RNA polymerase release (27). Further investigations into specific DNA elements and regulatory factors, will be instrumental to explain the differences in polymerase accumulation at divergent and termination regions.

Besides describing fundamental features of transcriptional activity in mosquito cells, PRO-seq enabled us to quantify direct changes in nascent RNA synthesis in response to immune challenge. Interestingly, a robust response was already seen one hour after stimulation. Hundreds of genes were upregulated, which exceeds the response after four hours. Upregulated genes at both time points included CLIP proteases and AMPs, which are important effectors of the mosquito immune response (13, 35). Intriguingly, other groups of genes were only enriched at either timepoint, such as heat shock genes at 4 hours. This delayed upregulation of genes related to heat shock and protein processing in the ER is reminiscent of a secondary stress response, potentially triggered by high levels of (secretory) proteins that are unfolded and/or need to be exported (50).

Remarkably, differences in temporal regulation were associated with distinct transcription factor binding motifs at the promotors of differentially expressed genes. NF-κB related motifs, indicative of regulation through the Toll and IMD pathways, were only enriched at promoters of transcripts showing sustained induction. In contrast, the GATA and AP-1 binding motifs, showed the strongest enrichment for transcripts only transiently induced at 1 hour. AP-1 transcription factors have frequently been associated with regulating transcription responses upon immune stimulation, often in concert with NF-kB signaling (51). Our data provide an intriguing temporal dimension to the differential activity of these two key immune transcription factors in the rapid responses in mosquito cells. It is intriguing to hypothesize that waves of gene expression in the early response to bacterial challenge enable a sophisticated coordination of genetic programs that fulfill distinct functionalities. Altogether our PRO-seq approach identified key gene regulatory elements and provided an advanced characterization of dynamic host responses to microbial challenge in mosquito cells.

caption.title: Genome-wide annotation of transcription start sites at nucleotide-resolution.
caption.p: A) Schematic of PRO-seq principle. Biotinylated nucleotides are incorporated by transcribing RNA polymerases, enabling the purification of nascent RNA for deep sequencing. The 3’ ends represent the polymerase position and 5’ ends the transcription start site. B+C) Genome browser image of PRO-seq, mRNA-seq and Initiator motif tracks. An example for PRO-seq 5’ nt coverage peaks coinciding with (B) and downstream of (C) the currently annotated transcription start site are shown (Source: VectorBase (VB) annotation) D) Distance between the transcription start nucleotide based on 5’ nt PRO-seq coverage or current start site annotation for all transcripts passing the filtering steps as described in Fig. S2A. E) Upper panel: Core promoter elements around the transcription start as described for D. melanogaster (27), including TATA box, Initiator (Inr) motif and downstream promoter element (DPE). Lower panels: Density distribution of core promoter elements around transcription start sites based on either the current gene annotation (yellow) or PRO-seq data (blue). The position of the underlined nucleotide in the sequence motifs of the TATA box (left) Initiator (middle), and downstream promotor element (right) is depicted. n indicates the number of identified core promotor elements in each dataset. F) Sequence motif generated for a 100 nt window around TSSs called by 5’ nt PRO-seq peaks (large panel) and the current gene annotation (insert).

caption.title: Transcription of the Ae. aegypti genome at genes and functional genomic regions.
caption.p: A) Schematic illustration of PRO-seq 3’ nt reads over genes, with distribution plotted as reported before for vertebrates (25). TSS indicates transcription start site and CPS indicates cleavage and polyadenylation site. B) Metaplot of PRO-seq 3’ nt coverage over all annotated genes (scaled, bin size of 10 nt), including 1 kb unscaled region on either end. C) Metaplot of PRO-seq 3’ nt coverage over the 200-nt window around transcription start sites (non-scaled, bin size of 1 nt). D, E) Genome browser images of PRO-seq 3’ nt, mRNA-seq, ATAC-seq and ChIP-seq tracks. Examples for genes that are actively transcribed (D) or transcriptionally inactive (E). F) Distribution of PRO-seq 3’ nt reads that mapped to genes over the functional genomic regions.

caption.title: Rapid and dynamic transcriptional response of Aag2 cells to immune stimulus.
caption.p: A) Experimental design: Aag2 cells were stimulated with heat-inactivated E. coli, chromatin for PRO-seq was harvested after 1 and 4 hours. B, C) MAplots of differentially expressed genes at 1h (B) and 4h (C) after immune stimulus. D) Annotation of upregulated genes into functional gene groups using DAVID. All groups with enrichment score > 1.5 are reported. The detailed functional annotation can be found in Fig. S4. Groups that were not significantly enriched at one of the timepoint are indicated as not significant (N.S.)

caption.title: Temporal expression patterns associate with distinct transcription factor motifs.
caption.p: A) Heatmap with z-scores of transcripts induced (log2 > 1) at either 1 or 4 hours after stimulation with heat-inactivated E. coli. Transcripts are clustered with k-means (k=3) using averages of biological duplicates as input. n indicates the number of transcripts in each cluster. B) Occurrence of transcription factor binding motifs that were enriched in either of the clusters (see Fig. S5). Numbers indicate the percentage of transcripts within the cluster that contain the motif in their promoter [TSS-1000, TSS]. The blue-red coloring denotes the log2 fold change over background (occurrences in all transcripts). Stars indicate p-value for enrichment as determined by HOMER with * for p < 0.05, ** for p < 0.01 and *** for p < 0.001. C) Schematic illustration showing the principle of temporal coordination of gene expression upon bacterial stimulation and potential transcription factors involved.
